abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p><jats:italic>Anania hortulata</jats:italic> (Linnaeus, 1758) (Lepidoptera: Crambidae: Pyraustinae) is a strikingly coloured, common, and widespread species that has long been recognised as a single species widely distributed in Asia, Europe, and North America. Using a combination of molecular and morphometric data, this study resolved that <jats:italic>A. hortulata</jats:italic> is actually a species complex of two superficially indistinguishable species. Phylogenetic and network analyses based on the mitochondrial COI gene discriminated lineages from all major geographical regions of China as distinct, <jats:italic>A. sinensis</jats:italic> Yang and Landry <jats:bold>new species</jats:bold>, whereas <jats:italic>A. hortulata</jats:italic> occurs in Central Asia, Europe, and North America. Nuclear gene (CAD) and morphological differences in the genital characters provided further evidence for the separation of <jats:italic>A. hortulata</jats:italic> and <jats:italic>A. sinensis</jats:italic>.</jats:p>
title: Allopatric separation represents an overlooked cryptic species in the Anania hortulata species complex (Lepidoptera: Crambidae: Pyraustinae): congruence between genetic and morphological evidence
